title: Best AI apps for Android
summary:

You can find productivity apps, social media apps, photo apps, and more that all leverage some form of machine learning and artificial intelligence to help you get stuff done.

title: How China is challenging Nvidia's AI chip dominance
summary:
How China is challenging Nvidia's AI chip dominance3 days ago Share Save Osmond Chia Business reporter Share SaveGetty Images Jensen Huang, the boss of Silicon Valley-based Nvidia, has warned China is "nanoseconds behind" the US in chipsThe US has dominated the global technology market for decades.
Last month, Jensen Huang - the boss of Silicon Valley-based AI chip giant Nvidia - warned that China was just "nanoseconds behind" the US in chip development.
There has also been no shortage of state-backed trade shows, promoting Chinese technology companies in a bid to attract investors.
China's chip industry has also yet to overcome criticism that its products can be less user-friendly than those of Western rivals like Nvidia.
Getty Images Chinese tech giant Huawei unveiled its plans to rival Nvidia's dominance in AI chips'Bargaining chip' for China

title: Jeff Bezos Has a Plan to Curb AI’s Carbon Footprint: Send Data Centers to Space
summary:
Jeff Bezos believes that for artificial intelligence to keep expanding, data centers will eventually need to move off the Earth and into space.
In turn, Bezos predicted that humans will start building gigawatt-scale orbital data centers within the next 10 to 20 years.
The next step is going to be data centers and other kinds of manufacturing.”Data centers are straining Earth’s resourcesAs tech giants pour billions into AI, data center construction is skyrocketing.
The concept of orbital data centers as a potential solution isn’t new.
We will be able to beat the cost of terrestrial data centers in space in the next couple of decades.”What’s more, orbital data centers would help reduce air and water pollution on Earth.

title: Impact of Anthropic's China ban unlikely to 'move the needle', expert says
summary:
While noting that the move was consistent with Anthropic's stance of advocating restricted Chinese access to US AI and chip technologies, Reynolds said mainland companies had been "extremely innovative" in developing AI models.
"Chinese users easily skirt Anthropic and OpenAI's geoblocking restrictions using mirror sites and VPNs," Ding said.
Anthropic's aggressive anti-abuse policy has seen many users lose their accounts even if they managed to register with the company.
Advertisement AdvertisementAdvertisement AdvertisementMeanwhile, Chinese companies have seized the opportunity to engage with more domestic users.
Analyst Reynolds said Anthropic's tough stance on China was "potentially [creating] a small opportunity for some of the Chinese players to pick up the business".

title: OpenAI just gave AMD a big boost in the AI chip wars
summary:
lighning bolt icon An icon in the shape of a lightning bolt.
The multi-year deal, announced Monday, will see OpenAI deploy 6 gigawatts of AMD GPUs, with the first 1 gigawatt deployment set to begin in the second half of 2026.
The move provides a significant boost to AMD against Nvidia, which is the dominant player in the AI chip market.
It's the latest example of OpenAI striking major AI chip partnerships.
In response to requests for comment, AMD and OpenAI directed Business Insider to statements on their press pages.

title: Eufy Offered $2 Payments for Real or Staged Footage of Package Theft
summary:
Smart security camera company Eufy offered owners of its products $2 to submit videos it could use to train its artificial intelligence software in a campaign that ran last winter.
As reported earlier by TechCrunch, Eufy launched a promotion to collect 20,000 videos of package thefts and 20,000 videos of people pulling on car doors.
For the purposes of the campaign, it didn't matter if the videos were real or if owners staged the videos.
The concept of services directly paying customers for data or content that will be used to train AI software is still fairly uncommon.
That app is currently on hold while the company addresses security issues, but the company's founder said it will return soon.

title: Google’s extreme smart home makeover
summary:
Over the last few years, you’d be forgiven for thinking the smart home was one of those things, as Google Home and Nest products seemed to languish behind their competitors.
But Google says it’s still in the game, and that Gemini is the key to making the smart home truly great.
On this episode of The Vergecast, David and The Verge’s Jennifer Pattison Tuohy are joined by Anish Kattukaran, head of product for Google’s smart home efforts, to talk about the state of the connected home.
Vee knows the pros and cons of multiple devices more than most, and helps our caller make the most of their wrists.

title: Why Lattice Semiconductor (LSCC) Stock Is Trading Up Today
summary:
Shares of semiconductor designer Lattice Semiconductor (NASDAQ:LSCC) jumped 3.3% in the morning session after a major AI-focused partnership in the chip sector boosted sentiment for stocks with exposure to the AI market.
Is now the time to buy Lattice Semiconductor?
Lattice Semiconductor is up 33% since the beginning of the year, and at $74.43 per share, it is trading close to its 52-week high of $74.71 from September 2025.
Investors who bought $1,000 worth of Lattice Semiconductor’s shares 5 years ago would now be looking at an investment worth $2,497.
